content: I was getting ready to graduate from the Master’s program in Materials Science at the University of Virginia. After being
injured and leaving the NFL my backup plan was to be an engineer in a topnotch chemical company.
At a career fair I met recruiters from several companies. I lined up interviews for promising jobs. Now I just had to get
through the process and choose the best offer.
The backup plan was shaping up nicely.
On the way out the door, I was hungry and focused on dinner. The next thing I knew a short black woman with a big smile
Who is this woman and why is she in my face? I wondered. But my mother raised me to be polite.
I looked down at her badge. It read ‘Rosa Webster: NASA Langley Research Center.’ “Leland Melvin,” I said, wanting to get
away from her so I could meet up with my friends at a restaurant.
“Leland,” she said, “you’re going to work at NASA.”
My first thought was, No, I’m not. I have a plan. But she never gave me a chance to say the words.
“I’ve been looking for you all day,” Rosa said. “We are looking for strong candidates and your name is at the top of my list.
Can you help me get these things to my car?”
I helped Rosa close down her booth and all the while she told me about working at NASA.
Hearing Rosa’s excitement about the cutting-edge science being done at the space agency, about their outreach to minority
graduates, and the opportunities in engineering research got my attention.
But I kept thinking, Who works at NASA? Certainly no one who looked like me. I imagined a line of all white guys in lab coats,
with crew cuts and clipboards, pushing paper for the government. Not my kind of club. I knew the pay would be better in private
industry. I believed the opportunities would be better too. I had a plan for my future. I was going to stick to the plan.
But I kept thinking about Rosa’s words and her excitement.
NASA had come looking for me. They wanted me, they had a job for me, she had said. Rosa kept her word and a few days later,
I received an official job offer from NASA. I asked myself, “Do I stick with the plan or do I want to further human exploration
